Description: Lower body sherd of Corinthian black-figured large pottery lekanis or lekane with turn to foot; interior: black-figure decoration consisting of part of Gorgoneion (part of eyebrow with added red dot, outer corner of left eye, left ear, freckles on ear lobe, neck, cheek and eyebrow; to right, tresses alternating in black and red remaining, with one curl of forehead fringe preserved); reserved band around tondo; surrounding area glazed black with two red bands; exterior: black-figure animal frieze (forelegs and one hind leg of grazing deer with red dots all over), facing to right; part of panther (only part of head and neck with red, chest and one front paw), to left; below, two streaky bands above frieze of fat rays at foot, with reserved band at turn to foot.
Curator's comments: The sherd belongs to the same vase as British Museum 1886,0401.1140.
Bibliographic references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum (B102.8.1)
Payne 1931 / Necrocorinthia. A study of corinthian art in the archaic period (p. 297, no. 718)
Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 90, no. A116)
Möller 2000 / Naukratis, Trade in Archaic Greece (p. 217, no. 11)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GB.109) (Phase 1)
